article.description: Chantelle Anderson scored 19 points to lead five players in double figures as eighth-ranked Vanderbilt captured its 12th consecutive First Tennessee Tournament championship with an 84-44 rout of Harvard.
article.headline: Anderson scores 13 of her 19 points in first half
article.linkText: Anderson earns happy trip to bench as Vandy rolls
article.story:
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) -- Chantelle Anderson didn't mind watching Vanderbilt from the bench this time.

   Anderson scored 13 of her game-high 19 points in the first half
to lead Vanderbilt (No. 8 ESPN/USA Today, No. 9 AP) past Harvard 84-44 on Sunday in the championship game of the First Tennessee Tournament.

	   The Commodores (4-0) built a 42-15 lead at halftime behind
Anderson and Jenni Benningfield, who scored all 12 of her points in
the first 20 minutes.

	   Harvard (3-1) never got started offensively, as Vanderbilt went
on a 14-0 run early in the first half to take an 18-3 lead, then
outscored the Crimson 20-2 over the last 10 minutes before the
break. Harvard shot 20.7 percent from the floor (6-for-29) in the
first half, and missed 17 of 19 3-point shots in that span.

	   The large lead allowed Vanderbilt coach Melanie Balcomb to
substitute freely, and none of the Commodores' starters played more
than 31 minutes.

	   "It was nice to be able to take some time on the bench happy,''
said Anderson, who was in foul trouble in the Commodores'
season-opening win at Boston and fouled out of their victory at
Syracuse. "It's the first time I've been able to do that in a few
games.''

	   Vanderbilt pushed the lead to 31 points with the first two
baskets of the second half, and led by as many as 52 inside the
final three minutes, before Harvard scored the game's last 12
points.

	   "This was the best game we've put together, offensively and
defensively,'' Balcomb said. "We've had games where we've played
well offensively, and games where we've played well defensively.
Today, we took care of both offense and defense.''

	   Ashley McElhiney scored 14 points for Vanderbilt, hitting all
four of her 3-point attempts. Tia Battle scored 13, and Ashley
Earley 10.

	   Harvard was led by Hana Peljto's 15 points. Reka Cserny had 12.
